Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation2: The deadline for closing the books for the month is approaching.
Story: I stared at the spreadsheet, numbers blurring together as the clock ticked closer to the monthly closing deadline. My phone buzzed again—my sister’s name lighting up the screen. She’d just gotten the news about her job, and her voice had cracked when she called earlier, asking if I could come over. I knew she needed me, needed her sibling to listen, to hold her hand through the shock and fear. But the emails from my manager kept piling up, each one reminding me of the importance of accuracy, of timeliness, of not letting the team down. My mind raced with the expectations: be the reliable accountant, keep the records flawless, don’t miss the deadline. But also, be the supportive sibling, the one who shows up when it matters most. My heart ached with guilt and anxiety, torn between the numbers on my screen and the pain in my sister’s voice. I sat frozen, unable to move, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding more than I could give.
